text.p: These are the leading stories in the Sarajevo press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Moslem-Croat federation government agreed on bill to create a body for the federation's implementation, it was said at the governement's session held in the divided town on Mostar on Thursday.
- Moslem chairman of Bosnia's collective presidency Alija Izetbegovic after his visit to the United States says that Washington backs Bosnia.
- Izetbegovic was given support from U.S. president Bill Clinton for Bosnia's joining NATO's Partnership for peace but he thinks that "we should not be too optimist regarding this issue".
- Bosnia's joint cabinet agreed on foreign trade and custom policy draft laws, Boro Bosic, co-chirman of the cabinet's session says.
- Bosnian Moslems and Croats partners agreed a power-sharing deal for Sarajevo's city government with signing the pact on Thursday night, state television reports.

- A new Sarajevo's mayor is supposed to be elected by April 10 two days before Pope John Paul II historic visit to Sarajevo, it was confirmed by the agreement on power-sharing deal for Sarajevo's city government.

- Deputy to minister for Bosnia's civil affairs and communication Nudzeim Recica thanks Germany which has spent so far 14 billion German Marks for 350,000 Bosnian refugees who were resettled there after the war in Bosnia broke out in 1992. DNEVNI AVAZ

- Full diplomatic relations between Fedral Republic of Yugoslavia and Bosnia Herzegovina should be established soon, Kasim Trnka, Bosnian amabassador to Croatia says in an interview given for Nasa Borba from Belgrade.
- Joint police forces in the southern Neretva canton should be established by April 15, Mostar radio reports.
- European Union imposed travel restrictions on three Croat policeman who had been involved in February 10 incident in Mostar, a press release issued by Royal Netherland Embassy in Sarajevo says.
- Provisional election Commission (PEC) charged with overseeing Bosnia's municipal elections sets April 25 deadline for local polls registration, Gerry Robinson, OSCE's senior adviser in Bosnia says.

- International supervisor for hotly disputed town of Brcko Robert Farrand is due to arrive to Sarajevo on Friday where he will meet Bosnian senior officials, a High representative official says. -- Sarajevo newsroom, +387-71-663-864.
